experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I’ll be honest—I’m pretty nervous, but I know I need to get better at talking to people, especially if I want to get into grad school.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! Totally normal to feel nervous—public speaking is a common challenge. Since you're already low in social anxiety, that's a huge advantage! Start small: practice explaining coding concepts to friends or join a tech club where you can present projects. Grad schools love clear communicators. You've got this—every great speaker started exactly where you are now.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try explaining some algorithms to my study group, but the thought of presenting at a tech club still makes my stomach hurt. It just feels like so much pressure to get it perfect for grad school applications.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart first step! Remember, tech clubs are full of students learning too—they'll get it. Perfection isn't the goal; showing growth and clarity is what grad schools value. Start with your study group, build confidence, then level up when you're ready. Progress over perfection!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess you're right. It's just hard not to think my code has to be perfect before anyone sees it. I'll try bringing it up in my study group on Thursday.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's the spirit! Sharing imperfect code is actually a strength—it shows you're open to feedback and collaboration, which grad schools and future employers really value. Good luck Thursday; you're taking a great step forward!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I guess. I'm still worried they'll think it's sloppy, but if you really think it's okay...

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Absolutely okay! Even senior developers share unfinished work—it’s how we improve. Your study group is there to learn together, not judge. If you’re nervous, try starting with: “I’d love feedback on this part I’m stuck on.” You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try that phrasing... it's just hard to believe they won't think my code is a mess compared to theirs.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Comparison is the thief of joy! Everyone’s code looks messy at some point—it’s part of the process. By asking for help, you’re showing initiative, not weakness. And honestly? They’re probably just as nervous about their own code. You’re in this together.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess you're right... it's just hard not to feel like I'm falling behind when I see how clean everyone else's projects look. But maybe I'll try asking my study group for help next time.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a fantastic step! Remember, those "clean" projects you see likely went through many messy drafts. Asking your study group not only helps you improve but also builds the collaborative skills that grad schools and tech teams highly value. You're not falling behind—you're learning in real time. Keep going!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess you're right... it's just hard not to compare my messy first draft to everyone else's finished work. I'll try to ask about it in study group tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s the spirit! Showing up with a “messy draft” takes courage—and it’s how real growth happens. Your willingness to be vulnerable and ask for input will actually earn respect, not judgment. You’ve got a solid plan—stick with it!

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Professors expect drafts to be messy—that’s why they’re called drafts! Showing your work early demonstrates initiative and a genuine desire to improve, which they appreciate far more than a "perfect" but last-minute submission. You're on the right track.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard not to feel like a messy draft reflects poorly on me, especially when I'm trying to get into grad school.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Think of it this way: grad schools look for students who can grow and accept feedback—showing a messy draft and improving from it actually demonstrates those qualities! Your professor will see someone eager to learn, not someone who's unprepared. You're doing exactly what strong candidates do.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard not to feel like I'm bothering them with something that isn't perfect yet.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Professors genuinely want to help students who take initiative—you're not a bother, you're showing engagement! Think of it as collaborating rather than imposing. They'll respect your proactive approach. You've got this.

turns.speaker: ai

Remember, professors were students once too, and they appreciate anyone making the effort to connect. You can do this!

turns.speaker: ai

Practice introducing yourself in low-pressure settings, like study groups. People are often friendlier than they seem! conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. Honestly, I'm only here because my academic advisor basically forced me to come. The whole "networking" thing is my absolute nightmare.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory, totally get it—networking can feel intimidating! But remember, it's just about making genuine connections. Start small: chat with professors after class or join an engineering club. Those casual interactions build confidence naturally. You're aiming for a research position, so maybe ask a professor about their work—people love sharing their passions. Small steps add up, and you've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but asking a professor feels like a huge leap. What if I freeze up or say something stupid? They're probably too busy anyway.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a super common fear! Professors were students once too—and most actually enjoy mentoring. Try preparing one simple question beforehand, like "What sparked your interest in this research area?" It shows genuine curiosity and gives you a script to fall back on. Remember, they said yes to meeting because they want to help!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but "they want to help" feels like a platitude. My question is, what if my genuine curiosity is just... boring? I don't want to waste their time.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Your curiosity isn't boring—it's your unique perspective! Professors often appreciate fresh questions that make them see their work differently. If you're really worried, frame it collaboratively: "I'm exploring research opportunities and was intrigued by your work on X. Would you be open to sharing what qualities you value in student researchers?" This shows initiative while keeping the focus on their expertise. You belong in these conversations!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That line feels so rehearsed though. What if I freeze up and just stare at them?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally normal to freeze! Try this: write your question on a notecard to glance at if needed. Even pros get nervous—admitting "I'm a bit nervous, but really interested in your work" can actually build rapport. It's humanizing, not unprofessional. You've got solid goals; a little preparation will help you own that conversation.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: A notecard? I guess I could try that, but telling someone I'm nervous feels like handing them a reason to write me off. What if they just think I'm not cut out for this?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Showing a little vulnerability often makes you more relatable, not less capable. Think of it this way: they’re not looking for a perfect robot—they want a curious, genuine person to collaborate with. If someone judges you for being human, that’s probably not the right mentor anyway. You’re not asking them to solve your anxiety; you’re showing up honestly. That takes courage, and courage is exactly what research requires.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But it feels like showing any weakness is just giving them a reason to pick someone else. What if "curious and genuine" just comes off as unprepared?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I hear you—it's a tough balance. But think about it: "unprepared" is showing up with no questions or interest. You're doing the opposite by researching their work and planning your approach. A brief, authentic moment like "I admire your research on X" before your question shows engagement, not weakness. Most professors value sincerity over polished perfection. You're not hiding a flaw; you're showing self-awareness, which is a strength in collaborative environments.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But what if my question is stupid? I've read their papers, but what if I just don't get it on the same level they do?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: No such thing as a stupid question when you're genuinely trying to learn! Professors *expect* undergrads to be at a different level—that's the whole point of mentoring. Try framing it like: "I read your paper on X and found Y fascinating. Could you help me understand how Z fits into that framework?" That shows you've done the work and are eager to grow. They'll appreciate your engagement way more than silence.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but what if Y *wasn't* fascinating? I just picked a random part. Feels like I'm faking it, and they'll see right through that.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Great point—authenticity matters. Instead of forcing fascination, pick something you're genuinely curious about, even if it's small. Try: "I noticed you used [specific method] in your paper. Could you walk me through why you chose that approach?" That's honest, shows you paid attention, and opens a real conversation. They respect curiosity more than flattery. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, but what if I pick the wrong detail and it just proves I didn't understand their paper at all? That feels like a bigger disaster than just staying quiet.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's actually a perfect opportunity! You could say: "I'm still developing my understanding of this field—could you help clarify how [detail] connects to your main findings?" That turns a potential "mistake" into showing humility and eagerness to learn. Professors love when students invite guidance. It proves you're engaged, not incompetent. Silence is the only real misstep here.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But what if I ask for clarification and they realize I have no idea what I'm talking about? That feels even worse than staying quiet.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's the secret—they *know* you're still learning. Asking for help shows self-awareness and a desire to improve, which is exactly what they look for in a research student. Try: "I'm working to deepen my understanding of this topic—could you point me toward resources to better grasp this concept?" That frames it as proactive growth, not ignorance. You're supposed to be curious, not an expert yet. That's why you're there!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But what if they just think I'm not cut out for it? That line sounds so... rehearsed.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that—it can feel awkward if it's too polished. Try just being real: "Honestly, this part went over my head a bit, but I'm really interested. Could you explain it like I'm new to the field?" Authentic curiosity is way more memorable than perfect phrasing. They’ve been where you are—they’ll appreciate the honesty. You belong there as much as anyone.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but the idea of admitting I don't get something to a professional makes my stomach drop. What if they just think I'm not cut out for this?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That fear is completely normal—it means you care. But think of it this way: every expert was once a beginner. Admitting you don't know something isn't a weakness; it's the first step to learning it. Most professors respect students who are brave enough to ask questions more than those who pretend to understand. Start small: pick one specific thing to ask about instead of a broad topic. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but it's not just about not knowing. It's about looking stupid in front of people who could give me a job or a research spot. I'll try the one specific thing, I guess.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great first step! And remember: looking "stupid" is often just in our heads. Asking thoughtful, specific questions actually makes you look *engaged* and *motivated*—qualities every researcher values. They're not judging your knowledge; they're judging your potential to learn. You're already on the right track by wanting to improve. Keep going!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but what if my specific question *is* actually stupid? It's not just in my head when I'm talking to a professor who's published a dozen papers.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Here's a secret: professors love "stupid" questions because they often reveal gaps in understanding that others are too afraid to ask about. If you're genuinely confused, chances are other students are too. Your question might actually help the professor explain concepts more clearly for everyone. That's not stupid—that's contributing to learning. You're not expected to know everything yet; that's why you're a student!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but when I ask something, it feels like everyone's just staring and waiting for me to mess up. What if the professor thinks I wasn't paying attention?

turns.speaker: ai

Try framing it positively: "I want to make sure I understand this correctly..." shows you *were* paying attention and care about getting it right. Professors appreciate that diligence. And if you're really worried, you can always ask after class one-on-one. You're being proactive, not unprepared!

turns.speaker: ai

This shows you *were* listening and are now diving deeper. Professors see this as dedicated, not inattentive. You've got this—taking that small step will build confidence each time.

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfectly okay to say: "That's a great question—let me think about that and get back to you." It shows you're thoughtful, not unprepared. Even professionals use this tactic! It gives you time to process without pressure. You're not expected to have instant answers—just genuine engagement.

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Actually, interviewers respect candidates who pause to think—it shows you don’t rush into half-baked answers. If you’re worried, add a quick summary first: “Based on what we discussed, my initial thought is X, but I’d like to consider it further to give a thorough response.” That shows confidence and depth, not hesitation. You’re demonstrating critical thinking, not stalling!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, but what if my brain just goes totally blank? I'm not just pausing, I'm panicking. They'll think an engineering major who can't think on his feet is a red flag.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that—panic makes logic vanish! Try this: take a slow breath and say, "Could you rephrase the question?" It buys you time, shows engagement, and often the rewording itself triggers an answer. Blank moments happen to everyone—handling them calmly is the real skill. You're not a red flag; you're human. Practice with a friend to build that reflex.

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai

turns.speaker: ai

Since you're interested in starting a student org and studying abroad, maybe we could focus on small, low-pressure steps that align with those goals. For example, joining an existing club first could help you ease into leadership. What’s one thing about communicating that feels manageable right now?

turns.speaker: ai

- Level: 6/10 (Moderate)

- Triggers: Large lecture halls
- Social comfort: 6/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Education

- Challenges: Dealing with homesickness, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Stays up late studying, Eats at the dining hall, Procrastinates on assignments

responses.question: I stay calm when I disagree with others.
